blocks.text:
Thus, 

$$ \frac{dM}{dx} = \frac{d}{dy} \left( \frac{M}{R} \right) $$ 

and 

$$ M = Ry $$

is used; whence double integration from the equation so formed gives an expression for the deflection of the beam.
A few harder cases are here taken: the beam not being simply supported.
A beam is fixed at one end and supported at the other; the loading is uniform, being the intensity $ w $ of the deflected form.

We must first find the form $ P $ (part of the couple keeping the end fixed). This being a constant, we can treat it as calculated on the assumption that the moment is the same everywhere. Referring to Fig. 109.

blocks.caption: Beam Uniformly Loaded
blocks.description: This figure illustrates a beam that is fixed at one end and supported at the other, with a uniformly distributed load across its length.

blocks.text:
Hence the actual bending moment is 

$$ M = \frac{w l^2}{8} - P x $$.

Now, by integration:

$$ \int M \, dx = \frac{w l^2}{8} x - \frac{P x^2}{2} + C_1 $$.
